          2 回顧與展望 
          2.1 黃精可以調節和增強免疫系統功能，顯著消除衰老動物體內自由基的增加，增強體內保護因素（SOD）。總之，目前的研究表明黃精可通過多種途徑

          能單用黃精或以黃精為主，設計出指標客觀，觀察嚴密的臨床藥理研究方案，從不同角度，不同途徑，不同方法進行研究，將有利於黃精延衰作用研究的發展。

Maladies Treated: heart and brain diseases due to lack of blood circulation
fever and headache in cold or flu
diarrhea in small children due to weak digestion
loose breasts in women with pixu (spleen deficient) condition
stubborn constipation with chronic fatigue and little speech due to spleen and stomach deficiency (pixu)
smell disappears after flu or cold
Medical Function: Effect on smooth muscle: Ge gen root contains ingredients (choline, acetylcholine, kassein, and others) that can cause contraction; the ether extract contains daidzin and daidzein, which inhibit mouse ileum contraction induced by acetylcholine (effectiveness is about 1/3 that of papaverine). Ge gen flavonoids, particularly daidzein, possess anti-acetylcholine effect and are mainly used in relieving spasm.
Anti-diarrhea.
Effect on coronary blood vessels: The active ingredient puerarin relaxes coronary and cerebral blood vessels.

Anti-arrhythmia: Puerarin, daidzein, and ethanol extract of ge gen show marked antagonistic effects against arrhythmias induced by aconitine and barium chloride in animal experiments. Ethanol extract and daidzein are stronger than puerarin. Puerarin shortens the duration of chloroform-adrenaline induced arrhythmias in rabbits and increases the threshold for ouabain-induced arrhythmias.

Enhances heart function: Ge gen total flavonoids and puerarin injected intravenously slow down heart rate, reduce total peripheral resistance, improve myocardial oxygen consumption efficiency, lower blood pressure, and slightly reduce left ventricular work (in animal experiments).
Lowers resistance of peripheral blood vessels.

Beta-adrenergic blocking effect: Puerarin can lower the maximal binding of beta-receptors on rat cardiac membrane and block activation of adenylate cyclase by adrenaline (observed in radioligand binding assays in animals).

Inhibits platelet coagulation: Puerarin inhibits ADP-induced aggregation of platelets in humans and animals, with a 50% inhibitory concentration of 0.43mg/ml in rats. Also inhibits 5-HT/ADP-induced platelet aggregation. Also markedly inhibits thrombin-induced 5-HT release in platelets.

Lowers blood sugar: Ge gen decoction lowers blood sugar in rabbits. Puerarin administered to alloxan-induced hyperglycemic mice at 500mg per dose significantly lowers blood sugar; 250mg approaches minimum effective dose. Combination of 250mg/kg/d puerarin and 50mg/kg/d aspirin maintained hypoglycemic effect for over 24h in mice; counteracts the hyperglycemic effect of epinephrine.

Inhibits growth of cancer cells and induces differentiation in cancer cells: Daidzein from ge gen inhibits HL-60 leukemia cell proliferation and induces differentiation from immature promyelocytes to mature granulocytes. Daidzein at 10-20μg/ml concentration inhibits B16 melanoma cell proliferation after 4 days and reduces tumor formation. Daidzein combined with Bc-4 from boswellia has stronger effect.

Anti-oxidation: Isolated PG1 (GP) and mangiferin (MF) from ge gen scavenge DPPH radical, inhibit oxidative hemolysis, and inhibit formation of peroxylipids by active oxygen species in microsomes. Therefore, both have free radical scavenging and antioxidant effects.

Improves memory: According to Liu Ganzhong et al, animal studies using mouse platform and rat operant conditioning found that ge gen alcohol extract and flavonoids reverse scopolamine (hydrobromide Scopolamine) and 40% ethanol-induced memory impairment. Alcohol extract counteracts scopolamine-induced inhibition of operant conditioning in rats. Scopolamine reduces mouse cortical and hippocampal acetylcholine and decreases hippocampal acetylcholine transferase activity; ge gen extract reverses this.
Biphasic body temperature regulation.
Improves eyesight.
Lactagogue: Young ge gen shoots are used as a galactagogue.
Bidirectional regulation of nitric oxide: Has heart-protective effect during heart attack.
Used in treatment of schizophrenia.
Prevention and treatment of brain disorders by promoting neuronal cytoarchitecture and synaptic functionality.

Enhances phagocytic function of macrophages in animals; ge gen decoction increases phagocytic capacity of liver and spleen for carbon particles, and restores immune function in animals with immune hyperactivity. Suppresses secretion of IL-1 (macrophages) and IL-2 (splenocytes) at certain concentrations; inhibits TNF, IL-1, and IL-2 secretion at higher concentrations.
Regular consumption of ge gen starch produces slender figure, developed breasts, fair skin, and relieves and improves menopause syndrome.
Expands blood vessels, removes body waste.
Beautifies skin and promotes weight loss.
Reduces addiction to alcohol and smoking.
Promotes osteoblast differentiation and bone formation by influencing ALP activity and mediating by estrogen receptor.
Dosage: 3 to 12 g (dried herb). If using fresh herb the amount can be a few times more (e.g., 3-12 g dried root, or up to several times more with fresh root).
Samples of Formulae:
For influenza, pneumonia, bronchitis, headache, chronic shoulder pain, skin inflammation, rheumatism, and loss of smell after flu or cold: Name of Formula: ge gen tang (Ge Gen Decoction).

For damp-heat with diarrhea: Name of Formula: ge gen qin lian tang (Ge Gen, Scutellaria, and Coptis Decoction).

For small children spitting milk or diarrhea due to weak digestion, and for women with loose breasts due to spleen deficiency (pixu): Name of Formula: qi wei bai zhu san (Seven-Ingredient White Atractylodes Powder).

Alcohol intoxication:
Formula 1: Smash fresh ge gen root to extract juice to make a drink (Qian Jin Fang).
Formula 2: Use ge gen starch to make porridge.

For alcohol intoxication and vomiting: Name of Formula: ge hua wan (Ge Flower Pill), from Pu Ji Fang.

For symptoms caused by overdrinking and retention of alcohol toxicity: Name of Formula: ge gen san (Ge Gen Powder), composed of Ge gen, Ge hua, Sha ren (Amomum fruit), etc., from Ru Men Shi Qin.

For thirst, vexation, and heat: Prepare porridge with ge gen starch (from Tai Ping Sheng Hui Fang).

For wind-heat toothache, mouth sores, sore throat, fever cough, high fever, headache, herpes, hemorrhoids, heat dysentery, diarrhea, drunkenness, and prostatitis: Use ge gen starch (as in Ben Cao Gang Mu and other sources).
Contraindications:
Do not use in cases of excessive sweating during summer.

Excessive use can harm digestive function.

Cases of hemolytic reaction, including death, have been reported following injection of puerarin (Radix Puerariae extract).

Do not add sugar when using ge gen starch to treat diarrhea.
Research:
Ge gen was first described in the Chinese materia medica, Shen Nong Ben Cao (200 B.C.). Both the roots and flowers have been used to treat alcohol abuse, drunkenness, and hangover ('jiu du' or alcohol poisoning) safely and effectively for over a thousand years in China. [1]

It has been tested for smoking addiction and has a similar effect, reducing addiction within one month.

Puerarin increases differentiation of osteoblasts via ALP activity and bone formation mediated by estrogen receptor. [1]

Harvard Medical School researchers reported that ge gen extract reduces alcohol intake in alcoholic rats. Rats injected with daidzin, daidzein, or daidzin were allowed to choose between plain water or alcohol-added water. Results showed rats with alcohol preference reduced alcohol intake by 50%. Trials are underway in the US for treating alcohol intoxication.

According to the National Research Institute of Chinese Medicine, ge fen (ge gen starch) is rich in high-grade starch, carbohydrates, protein, flavonoids (including puerarin, puerarin-xyloside, daidzein, and arachidic acid), as well as vitamins B, C, E; minerals such as calcium, zinc, phosphorus, potassium, and various amino acids. Flavonoid content is reportedly four times the value of gold. 'Wild' ge fen from ecologically protected areas is said to have higher medicinal value and more pronounced effectiveness for prevention and treatment of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary heart disease, angina, diabetes, cancer, and skin sarcoma. Regular consumption is claimed to lead to a slender body, developed breasts, fair skin, and relief/improvement of menopause syndrome.
Notes:
Ge fen (ge gen starch) is highly regarded in traditional Chinese medicine for therapeutic effects including quenching thirst, clearing heat, detoxifying, preventing sunstroke, skin care, weight loss, and promoting vascular dilation. It is also claimed to have the function of clearing internal waste.
